TextEquiv.Unicode: maunded to stick to God only & to im
brace him alone. For to whom we doe
wholly owe al that we have, to him is
al the whole sincerely, simply and fully
to be given. Heere are they condem
ned, whosoever wil not once love God
and the world together. The Lord re
quireth the whole heart, the whole
mynde, the whole soule, and all the
strength, finally he requireth all what
soever we are, or have in possession :
he leaveth nothing therefore for thee
to bestowe on other. By what right
then wilt thou give to the fleshe, the
Divell, to other Gods or to the world:
the thinges that properly are Gods
owne: And God verily alone is the
chiefest, eternall, greatest, mightiest,
creator, deliverer, preserver, most gen
tle, most iust, and best of all. Jee alone
doth give, hath given, and is able to
give to man all that is erpedient for
the safegarde of his body and soule.
God alone doth minister to man abi
litie to live well and blessedly : and
therefore God deserueth to bee loved
alone, and that too before and above al
other thinges. This love of God doth
blesse all the haps and chances of men,
and turneth them to their profite, ac
cording to that saying, To them that
love God all thinges worke for the
best. This love of God also containeth
this, that it suffereth us not to honor,
worship, reverence, feare, or cal uppon
any, neither to trust in, obey or sticke
to any other, but to the one and only
God, to whom al glory is due.
But now before we speake of the
love of our neighbour, it is requisite
that wee first shewe who it is that is
our neighbour, touching which I see
some men to doubt and sticke uncer
tainely. For some there are that take
their kinffolkes to be their neighbors,
Other some there are that thinke that

maunded to stick to God only & to im brace him alone. For to whom we doe wholly owe al that we have, to him is al the whole sincerely, simply and fully to be given. Heere are they condem ned, whosoever wil not once love God and the world together. The Lord re quireth the whole heart, the whole mynde, the whole soule, and all the strength, finally he requireth all what soever we are, or have in possession : he leaveth nothing therefore for thee to bestowe on other. By what right then wilt thou give to the fleshe, the Divell, to other Gods or to the world: the thinges that properly are Gods owne: And God verily alone is the chiefest, eternall, greatest, mightiest, creator, deliverer, preserver, most gen tle, most iust, and best of all. Jee alone doth give, hath given, and is able to give to man all that is erpedient for the safegarde of his body and soule. God alone doth minister to man abi litie to live well and blessedly : and therefore God deserueth to bee loved alone, and that too before and above al other thinges. This love of God doth blesse all the haps and chances of men, and turneth them to their profite, ac cording to that saying, To them that love God all thinges worke for the best. This love of God also containeth this, that it suffereth us not to honor, worship, reverence, feare, or cal uppon any, neither to trust in, obey or sticke to any other, but to the one and only God, to whom al glory is due. But now before we speake of the love of our neighbour, it is requisite that wee first shewe who it is that is our neighbour, touching which I see some men to doubt and sticke uncer tainely. For some there are that take their kinffolkes to be their neighbors, Other some there are that thinke that
their benefactors are their neighbors,
&iudge them strangers that doe them
any harm. But our Lord Jesus Christ
telleth us, that every one, yea, though
he be our enemie is neverthelesse our
neighbour, if hee stand in neede of our
aide or counsell. For he imagineth ye a
Jewe, lighting among theeves and li
yng on the high way halfe dead, and
covered with woundes and swelling
drye blowes, was not regarded of his
owne countrey men, a Levite, and a.
Priest that passed by him, but at last
was taken up and healed by a Sama
ritane. Now there was a deadly eni
mitie betweene the Jewes and the
Samaritanes: yet notwithstanding
this Samaritane doth good to the Jew
because he saw that the case and ne
cessitie of the afflicted man did, so re
quire. Nowe therefore the Lorde ap
plying this to his owne purpose de
maunded of him, that desired to learne
who was his neighbour, and sayeth,
which of these three seemeth to thee to
have beene this mans neighbour, Hee
aunsweared, Hee that shewed mercy.
Then said the Lord, Goe thou and
doe the like. As if he should have said,
like as the samaritane iudged even
his enimy to bee his neighbour, and
dealt friendly with him when he stood
in neede of his friendshippe: so see that
thou take every one that needeth thy
helpe to bee thy neighbour, and do him
good. Aurelius Augustine therfore, ac
cording to the right sense of the Scrip
ture sayde, wee take him to bee our
neighbour, to whom wee shew mer
cy when neede requireth, or to whom
we should shew mercy, if at any time
hee should neede. Wee Suitlers doe.
most properly expresse it, when we call
our neighbour, Den nachsten mens
chen, that is, any man without diffe
rence whosoever by hap shall light in

their benefactors are their neighbors, &iudge them strangers that doe them any harm. But our Lord Jesus Christ telleth us, that every one, yea, though he be our enemie is neverthelesse our neighbour, if hee stand in neede of our aide or counsell. For he imagineth ye a Jewe, lighting among theeves and li yng on the high way halfe dead, and covered with woundes and swelling drye blowes, was not regarded of his owne countrey men, a Levite, and a. Priest that passed by him, but at last was taken up and healed by a Sama ritane. Now there was a deadly eni mitie betweene the Jewes and the Samaritanes: yet notwithstanding this Samaritane doth good to the Jew because he saw that the case and ne cessitie of the afflicted man did, so re quire. Nowe therefore the Lorde ap plying this to his owne purpose de maunded of him, that desired to learne who was his neighbour, and sayeth, which of these three seemeth to thee to have beene this mans neighbour, Hee aunsweared, Hee that shewed mercy. Then said the Lord, Goe thou and doe the like. As if he should have said, like as the samaritane iudged even his enimy to bee his neighbour, and dealt friendly with him when he stood in neede of his friendshippe: so see that thou take every one that needeth thy helpe to bee thy neighbour, and do him good. Aurelius Augustine therfore, ac cording to the right sense of the Scrip ture sayde, wee take him to bee our neighbour, to whom wee shew mer cy when neede requireth, or to whom we should shew mercy, if at any time hee should neede. Wee Suitlers doe. most properly expresse it, when we call our neighbour, Den nachsten mens chen, that is, any man without diffe rence whosoever by hap shall light in
